Comments_List: I learned how to be a methodical scientist who follows the scientific method rigorously. I learned how to effectively communicate my findings.
Basics of chemistry lab that are seen in AP Chemistry, but with more extension. I also REALLY learned my sigfigs.

I also learned about the origin of several constants/accepted values such as molar mass, Avogadro's constant, and the Ideal Gas Constant. Overall, this course taught me a lot about practical chemistry.
I definitely got a better understanding of how chemical reactions work by seeing them played out in real life.  Skills I especially learned were titration and measuring the volume of gas.

Basic chemistry lab skills such as how to carry out electrolysis and titrations and the basic concepts that are underlie these experiments.

This was without a question the worst course I have taken at Yale. Students will learn the most basic of lab skills. For instance, the course teaches students to perform titrations, set up an electrolytic cell, and other similarly basic procedures. Most students have already learned these things in their high school chemistry courses. If they have not, the amount of time and frustration that this course generates does not make these skills worth it. Lectures are unhelpful, as they review concepts from General Chemistry without highlighting anything new about the content, or revealing an interesting angle. The process of completely lab reports is not educational, as they are graded based on Dr. G's extremely particular preferences (that students just have to guess until they get a stupid number of points deducted for highly specific and irrelevant things). The experiments themselves are also not designed for efficient learning. They seem to be more geared towards forcing students to take repeated measurements than anything else.
The class taught very basic lab skills and procedure. Most of the values determined by the labs were constants that had already proven many times prior.
I became better at using Microsoft word and excel. Additionally, I learned how to write formal lab reports and carry out experiments in a precise and accurate fashion.

The experiments were literally just following a set of instructions and knowing what to expect, so it wasn't very interesting. All the concepts were explained in my actual chemistry course, so I overall felt that I didn't really learn much in this course.

CHEM 134L is a course that introduces students to the fundamentals of laboratory practice, by guiding them through ten experiments that focus on different lab skills. Through this course, I got acquainted to common lab practices and learned the basic principles of empirical practice of chemistry. As a person with minimal lab experience, this course helped me gain an understanding of the workings of a lab and introduced to the use of basic equipment and practices.Through the experiments I learned to pay attention to detail -- even to an extreme amount at times -- and learned how to utilize the data I collected to understand the chemical processes that we were studying.
I developed the skills needed to record data properly and then use that data for scientific findings.
I learned how to perform several fundamental techniques in the field of chemistry.
I learned the basics of the chemistry laboratory and how to write a lab report, including how to make the graphs included within a report.
I learned how to do certain chemistry experiments and use different lab equipment.
I gained some nice study habits but I honestly had trouble grasping course material and how it built as the class went on.
I gained slightly more knowledge than I had about laboratory chemistry.

I believe this course enhanced the subjects we were learning in General Chemistry 161 since many of the experiments showed the practical side of many of the topics we covered. I also learned about the basics of working in a college-level laboratory, especially the diligence needed for a laboratory notebook and lab reports. I believe it will provide me with a good basis for proper conduct in labs.

The strengths of the course is the breadth of experiments and the amount of resources available to students. The weaknesses of the course are related to the amount of time required to complete the work (both inside and outside the lab).

The quizzes can be pretty unforgiving - it's easy to make one mistake and end up nearly failing the quiz. I think a strength of this course would be its preparation for the next chem lab section, but a weakness is the lack of instruction/feedback you get on lab reports from prelab lectures and the manuals, which lead to getting annoying points off lab reports.

Strengths-
-Easy to follow manuals
-Interesting and Engaging Content
-Taught the pre-lab lecture well
Weaknesses-
-Grading was based on some somewhat unimportant things on lab reports, such as passive voice, that did not have to do with chemistry itself
-Pre-lab quizzes were often very difficult, even if one prepared for them
-Course was more concurrent with those taking CHEM 161 and not those in CHEM 163
Improve-
-Change grading to reflect chemistry portion of lab reports
-Make sure the quizzes and material are on material covered in 163 as well as 161

Dr. G is really passionate about chemistry and teaching chemistry. He's really open to questions and a good lecturer. However, sometimes points were taken off for super arbitrary reasons and there aren't really rubrics for grading so the points you can lose are basically limited.

The strength of this course are that you really do learn a lot, and doing the labs gets easier/makes more sense as you go through the semester.
The main weakness is that sometimes it seems overly stressful for what it is, and you can get points off on lab reports for things you didn't know you had to do (like including the reactions taking place when writing your purpose).

A strength of the course is its structure, with a prelab lecture, quiz and then the lab itself. It could be improved by always having lab equipment which works and is not old, as this has on occasion made lab difficult for me.

Experiments are interesting and pre-lab lectures are helpful and enriching. It is a great course however it is quite time consuming. Grading policies focus too much on format rather than content. This class should definitely be 1 credit (I realize the instructor has no control over this). Also, lab reports are not graded until the next one has been turned in. This means that if you are marked down for making a mistake on one lab report, you cannot change your mistake for the next lab report since it has already been turned in.

The course is very useful to learn the basic skills required in a chemistry laboratory, however, it is a very demanding course with what feels like disproportionate returns. I feel it could be improved by receiving more clear and concise feedback related to the conceptual understnding of the material rather than just for the mechanical mistakes made.

This course is engaging because performing a lab requires you to be attentive and careful at all times. Of course, it was also very tiring. Lab was a good supplement to Chem 161, since the topics were usually similar.

Some of the experiments, such as determining the Universal Gas Constant R, require an unnecessary degree of precision to receive credit. For example, the gas constant experiment required getting three runs within three percent of the actual value, even though there were many possible errors out of the students' control, such as a leaky experimental setup. I didn't feel like I learned more from getting a value within 3% as opposed to 5%. I think the class should focus more on learning experimental procedures than getting the exact right results.
Because the workload is decent, the class should be a full credit.

Strengths: Spending 4 hours with the same group of people each week in a lab is a surprisingly nice way to make friends.

Weaknesses: Only 1/2 credit despite meeting 3-4 hours a week (while the average 1 credit class meets for 2 and a half hours per week). Additionally, the lab reports were extremely tedious and seemed like they were not graded for content but rather for the inclusion of certain "buzzwords," and even small details being omitted or mistake would cost you a lot. Additionally, we were often assessed on material that we did not learn in class. For example, one of our quizzes featured a concept that had yet to be introduced in Chem 161, and the instructor said that we should have known it from high school. That really doesn't seem fair or educational to me.

Strengths:
- Prelab lectures 
- Breadth of experiments 

Weaknesses:
Feedback came back to slowly. Our labs were always graded a week or two behind, which made preparation hard.

While I definitely took a lot out of the course in terms of reinforcing chemistry concepts and learning how to use lab equipment, I think the course has a lot of room for improvement. While many weeks we used classical procedures such as titrations or calorimeters, I think that there was no need to force values to be within 3% of the accepted value because that made the lab very stressful and many students ended up forging data, thereby teaching the wrong values of science. Additionally, I though the lab deriving the universal gas constant, while cool to understand the gas constant, was extremely painful and tedious, making for an unpleasant time in the lab. I think a strength was that Dr. G was very helpful when writing up lab reports and explaining concepts relevant for the lab and being flexible with rescheduling lab.

This course is a necessary evil, although sometimes I found it to be more evil than necessary. Sometimes the lab lectures were a little long, but the lab quizzes (usually) focused on the relevant / necessary / important concepts of the lab. I don't think I learned how to do anything spectacular or significant during this course, most of it was just weighing things and mixing things together. This course needs to be a whole credit. I often spent more time in lab than I did in lecture. Similarly, the lab report takes just as long as homework from lecture. Also, I found the lab grading to be somewhat inconsistent throughout the lab reports - sometimes points were taken off for a particular detail, while, other times, points were not taken off. I never really knew what was expected for lab reports, even though I followed instructions listed in the syllabus.

I actually liked this lab a lot. I thought it facilitated my learning and gave me just enough independence to learn for myself why the experiment in question was being performed. It helped me kindle my love for science. In terms of how it can be improved, I would just say to give more time on the experiments where the answers must be in a certain error range. I know several students who could not get in the range, but they didn't seem to be doing anything wrong.
The point system for the lab reports was ambiguous. I never knew exactly where I could get points off or where I could gain extra points.

The strengths are learning how to use lab equipment as it is a basic intro class. However, this class took so much effort and hour put into the lab reports way more than all my other classes. I feel it definitely should be worth a full point. Also, not taking AP chem prior to this class, I did not know a lot of the info we were doing in the labs therefore did terrible on the quizzes. If we had a couple lectures and like practice problems of how to do some of the math beforehand, I feel i would have done better on the quizzes.
This was a very effective Lab course. It was a great way introductory lab course for students who didn't do many labs in high school that were to the caliber of college chemistry.
The quizzes weren't ideal & the lab reports were graded ridiculously, but I believe I gained a better understanding of chemistry through applying the skills.

Lab reports are insanely time-consuming for a .5 credit course and weekly quizzes are stressful and often unrelated to writing the lab report. The grading nitpicks at the smallest of details and strangles the joy of working in a lab. In response to criticism about the time this class takes, the professor said "maybe you should improve your work habits" and that the quizzes "are meant to be stressful". Dr. G is a stubborn man who, while having a genuine interest in chemistry, has no interest in the well-being of his students.

I really liked the experiments that we were doing because of how relevant they were to our lecture course work. I wish that the assignments would have been returned in a more timely manner, and I would have liked the expectations to be more clearly posted.

Strengths: TAs are good, pre lab lectures are very informative, labs chosen are engaging

Weaknesses: style of grading, lack of compassion from Dr G

The strength is that it is largely about following the directions to perform the lab. I think that the pre-lab lectures are super insightful. I also understand that the quizzes are meant to encourage learning of the materials but I also feel that there was no real way to study for them beforehand. I think that one of the shortcomings of this course was in the grading of the lab reports. I think that too often there was not enough clarity in the expected content to be included in a lab report. I can also recall some TA taking point for things like stylistic choice in formatting that I thought were subjective.
This course does a very good job and making sure everyone does what is required of them, and serves as a very effective teaching tool.

Strengths: labs are manageable and you usually get out much earlier than 5pm (unless you mess up on one of the labs that require really long runs). Most of the TAs are nice and helpful. 

Weaknesses: Pre-lab lectures can get redundant and can sometimes be a lot longer than necessary, but are generally helpful on the quiz immediately after.

There is far too much emphasis on trivial aspects of chemistry, like significant figures. Also, it was very frustrating that the lab grades for each week were released the day after the lab for the current week was due, because if I made a mistake on a lab report, it was very likely that I made the same mistake on the next lab report. It was also far too easy to lose points on weekly quizzes.
The course was well organized, but the only issue was that the grading for the lab reports seemed to follow a weirdly specific rubric, taking off too many points for small errors.

The class helped me get comfortable with a lot of different equipment. The quizzes made sure I understood the material. The labs were entertaining and I enjoyed doing them. The lab report pages were extremely helpful for guiding me through the work. I didn't really think there were many weaknesses.

This course is good at getting people acquainted with a typical chemistry lab setting, but that is pretty much it. It is extremely difficult to understand what Dr. G is expecting from the students, and often the TFs don't have any more information than the students do. Overall there is a lack of information and communication.

I think this course was really good at teaching me how to use lab equipment and was a good introduction to science lab. However, sometimes I felt that topics were under explained. The topics were taught the day of the lab, and I felt that it was hard to learn about the topic from just the manual and a quick lecture. Also, sometimes I felt like the labs were graded inconsistently. On some labs I would do a specific part of the lab correctly, then on the next lab I would get points taken off for the same thing.

The real strength of the class of Dr. G's office hours. Make friends with Dr. G and go to his office hours. He really wants you to succeed and will gladly answer questions you have. I went every single week and they were always so helpful, and it will show in your grades. I would have liked for the material in lab to be more closely related to the information learned in General Chemistry.

A lot of the experiments don't seem very real or relevant. I understand you can't give very difficult experiments and I wouldn't want that, but experiments that are time consuming and annoying that just confirm existing constants aren't very interesting. However, the pre-lab lectures were always very helpful.

Strengths: Learned the chemsitry. Learned to write lab reports. Lectures were clear and useful.

Weaknesses: None. This was a fantastic course in my opinion.

The grading for lab reports doesn't feel transparent; since each lab was different, it felt impossible to write up a perfect lab report. Everything about this course was made in a formulaic way, which also isn't how real science works. Lab manual was very dense, which I feel didn't have to be the case. The main strength of this course was the clarity of the pre-lab lecture.

Strengths: It only meets once a day.

Weaknesses: The lab reports do not get graded fast enough, so you do not have enough time to correct subsequent mistakes because you don't know what you did wrong on the previous lab report. Also, the environment in Chemistry Lab is not welcoming. It is a shame that an introductory class would have such a strict environment that suggests that the people running the class do not want them to get good grades.

One strength was the use of TAs. Made the lab run a lot more smoothly since I always had someone to ask for help.

The worst weakness was the use of pre-lecture quizzes. The Chem 163 students don't learn the same material as 161, so we have to learn extra material just to stay on par with the rest of the class. It's very stressful.

A strength of the course is the experiments that are done. I think they were engaging and provided a good exposure to introductory chemistry, and the lectures usually gave a good background to the experiments. The course could be improved if not so much emphasis was placed on sigfigs. I have to spend so much time watching sigfigs.
well organized, enthusiastic professor, helpful TAs

The class has a very high workload. Many of the corrections on the lab reports were unnecessarily harsh; it is unclear of what is expected on the lab report and it is penalized when minute or insignificant details are missing.

I found the time spent in the lab in this course to be relatively interesting and even fun. The experiments were clearly designed with a lot of thought and care. 
Despite this, I found this course to be one of the most unenjoyable courses I have taken in a long time, probably since middle school. There is a ridiculous amount of time spent outside of the lab completing lab reports that are intellectually uninspiring and unimaginably tedious. I can confidently say I gained absolutely nothing out of any of the 3-4 hours (one lab report took many students and I 10 hours to finish) I spent on each lab report other than becoming skilled at plugging numbers into a calculator and typing in the results into an excel spreadsheet.

I have nothing against the idea of assigning students lab reports after they complete an experiment. If designed well, such assignments can help students develop their scientific writing skills, better understand the relevance of what they did in the laboratory, understand the equations they used in their work on a deeper level, and learn how to present data in a clear and concise manner. The only thing Dr. Ganapathi's lab reports attempt to do is teach students to present data clearly. Other than this, the lab reports fail in every one of the areas I outlined. They are simply fill-in-the blank worksheets in which students have to mindlessly plug numbers into formulas, write out all of the equations they used in a word processor, and fill in tables. All of this takes a very long time and is highly unrewarding and unpleasant. The "concept" questions at the end of the lab are an attempt at trying to get students to think a little more critically, but they are usually very surface level and are not a significant portion of the work done. I would suggest that there should be much less emphasis put into these tedious calculations. All the students are going to forget what they did anyway, and it is just a waste of time. I think these labs would have been much more rewarding if there was more of a writing component involved that forced students to demonstrate that they actually understood what is happening in the reactions they are performing and why they are using the specific measurement techniques that they are.
The time spent for this course was way too high for half a credit. It should either be worth more or the reports should not be as meticulous.

I think the steps and instructions for every lab were very detailed and specific, but sometimes the information can get a bit convoluted. I also feel that the expectations from the professor were also made clear. I did find some of the work and some of the information in the lab reports to be a bit tedious.

The course often complemented Chem 161, so it was interesting to see ideas we learned in class actually carried out in an experiment. I found that the weekly pre-lab lectures were very useful, and, though the weekly quizzes weren't exactly pleasant, they were generally helpful. I took issue with when the quizzes required a degree of memorization which seemed unnecessary.
This course was very engaging and a great supplement for the material I learned in chem 161, however, the grading for the lab reports was unreasonably harsh.
Very good course in experiment learning. Very interesting in general.

The course challenges your patience and effectiveness in the laboratory. 

However, I retained very little from the course and found that its setup facilitated a transactional and somewhat empty class experience.
The experiments are very applicable to what we learn during Chemistry 161 and are very helpful to learn about various chemistry topics, ranging from oxidation-reduction reactions to the gas laws.

This course effectively showed how the concepts of chemistry are applied in the laboratory. However, the requirements for the lab reports were unclear. I think a rubric detailing the requirements would have been nice.

Strengths of this course included engaging and fun labs that I was actually interested in. Dr. G's enthusiasm for chemistry was also prevalent throughout the entire course. Additionally, Dr. G answered any questions I had quickly and with great answers.

Weaknesses of this course were that towards the end of the course, the labs ended up not being as fun as at the beginning of the semester. Additionally, the quizzes that we all took before each lab didn't always seem fair. The material of these quizzes were often graded harshly and they often didn't really seem to go with the lab at hand.

The course forces students to type out lab reports in such a way that it takes approximately 7 hours to complete what should be a 3-hour lab report. The only strength of this course would be having hands-on experience in topics we are learning during the general chemistry course.

This course is just not great. It's fine, everybody gets through it, but the grading is kind of arbitrary (what's even more annoying is that the grading is delayed so you don't get one lab report back before you submit the other and so you have no way to know about/fix the errors you made on the previous one so they don't carry over to the next lab report) and the experiments don't really help you understand chemistry all that much more. I would say the workload is definitely a half-credit, but not a full credit. The only real way that I see to improve this course is to make it less concerned with having lab reports that conform to Dr G's high standards, which causes a lot of stress among students, and make it more about enjoying chemistry and having fun with it. The best lab day was when we had to do a bunch of reactions to figure out the identity of "mystery" solutions because then it was about problem-solving. The problem with the experiments was that they were already set out for you and so you just stood around for a long time in the lab not doing anything interesting, and you would already kind of know what the results would be (like in the gas lab). That definitely lowered the engagement and made it somewhat uninteresting.

for students taking 163 there wasnt enough support in preparing for the quizzes because I hadn't seen these topics since high school and would have liked more than a brief lecture the day-of to review quiz topics. Seeing more practice problems reflective of what was going to be on the quizzes prior to the actual day of the quiz would have helped. Also, I was rarely able to view feedback on labs and/or there were no comments given to me so I could not improve if I didnt know what I was doing wrong.

I think the course focuses a lot on the particulars of chem lab which is great. I found myself very intently reviewing the lab manual and attempting to understand procedure. I think Dr. G is doing an amazing job of making sure students are engaged and fully challenging themselves in a course that easily presents itself as an easy course.
Strengths: good interaction with material learned in gen chem 1. No significant weaknesses.
NO STRENGTHS. ALL WEAKNESSES

Weakness: I wish there was a rubric published students could look at for each report. A policy changed midsemester (showing calculations in lab notebook) that was not forewarned. Also could be 3 instead of 4 hours if only 1/2 a credit
There was an excessive amount of tedious work for lab reports and some of the information in the manual felt unnecessary.

The grading is a HUGE weakness. The quizzes, which we were only given 15 minutes to complete, were unnecessarily difficult. The lab report rubrics were way too critical...two points were taken off my lab report because I had forgotten to include the word 'Vernier' in my phrase 'gas pressure sensor'; why do you even need the word Vernier in the lab report? It's literally the name of a company/brand. Other than that, it was nice that our lowest lab report and quiz could be dropped, but the class was still pretty stressful. I did appreciate the pre-lab lecture/information Dr. G presented in class, as it made me more confident about the experiment we were about to do after the quiz.
The grading of the lab reports could be a bit less strict.

Although tiresome, I think the lab reports and the quizzes were strengths of the class as they help reinforce knowledge learned in class and in the labs. They made it so that we were just mindlessly doing work in the lab. One weakness however I feel is the structure of the class, mostly due to the large amount of students in the lab. Often times, people had to wait to use equipment which often wasted time for many.

Some strengths of this class is that it is pretty straight forward what you are responsible for. However, the course has many weakness. To begin, you do not receive you lab report grades from the previous week until after you turned in your lab for the current week. This is frustrating because you cannot correct you mistakes and learn off of them until the next lab report. Also, this class is very much tailored to Chem 161, so if you are in Chem 163 or took AP Chemistry a long time ago, you have to put forth the extra time to review the topics that will be on the pre-lab quizzes.
It is a lot of work for .5 credits. I think that the lab reports are graded very strictly and there's no clear rubric on how to do better

While the labs are relatively engaging and well taught, the amount of work that one has to put into this class and the fact that it's only .5 of a credit is absolutely ridiculous. It's a huge time commitment and the level of rigor applied to the work, not to mention how hard it is to get an A, should contribute to a full credit. Also the lack of consistency in lab grades was positively infuriating, and I think there should be a much clearer standard.
The lab manual could be improved, as it was difficult to understand at times and a bit wordy.
It was too picky and I was never sure what was expected from us on lab reports.
The strength is the ability of the course to teach lab procedures. The weakness is its value as only half a credit. More homework and twice as much class time as a normal class but half the credit.
Overall, the course is a decent introduction to general chemistry lab techniques. However, the lab report grading is inconsistent. Graders differ in how "nit picky" they are.

Strengths: helpful TAs, lab reports are pre-formatted (which significantly reduces the time needed to complete them)
Weaknesses: Dr. G is kind of terrifying, the severity of grading changes every week
This course could be improved by having the experiments align with what is being taught in chem lecture that week, so that the concepts from class would be reinforced in the lab.

Strengths:
- teaches how little forgiveness exists in the scientific community when conducting scientific experiments
- how to use time efficiently 
- provides a review of important chemistry topics that are not taught in chemistry class (Chem 163)
Weakness:
- subjective grading system where the same answer can be graded differently depending on who is grading
- inconsistent instruction for lab equipment use as well as lab report write-ups
- incorrect use of significant figures

A weakness of this course is there is not much room for creativity or trials that are not meticulously planned out in advance. Every element was written in the lab manual, which was helpful during experiments, but this meant that there was not much knowledge coming from the experiment that had not been written out in advance.

Strength: The material mostly matched what I was learning in Chem 161 which is pretty helpful.

Weakness: The flow of the lab experiments is not super organized and I don't think students in Chem 163 would understand the experiments as well. The inconsistency in grading among the TAs

Strengths: Introduction to working in a lab, instructor was very strict, which is a good thing in my opinion (teaches work discipline and precise working for future tasks/jobs etc.)
Weaknesses: A lot of time commitment for only 0.5 credits!!! Prelab Lectures are sometimes pointless regarding the procedure that follows. The labs sometimes do not relate to the contents learned in Chem 161 at the same time, some are too early in the semester, some are too late. Most procedures are not exciting at all and the material/instruments used were often poor quality.

The lecture component of the course is fine. Dr. G is a strong lecturer, and presents material efficiently and effectively. Everything else about this course is horrendous. Student feedback is extremely low, so it is almost impossible to improve your performance over the course of the semester. The grading is unreasonable, mostly because the standards by which students are graded is detached from the actual content, and has to do with wording minutiae or the layout of one's graphs, which is honestly a pedagogically horrible way to evaluate student's knowledge of an experiment.

The class was not formatted well. The lab reports were incredibly difficult to do well on and the feedback given on the reports was always very confusing and unclear. In addition, pre-lab quizzes were stressful and often tested knowledge that had not been covered in the class or other subsequent chemistry courses, something which felt unfair.

Strengths: helpful pre-lab lectures, some of the experiments were engaging, learned a good amount about chemistry 

Weaknesses: very arbitrary grading on the lab reports (especially on the "purpose" section), quiz questions sometimes seemed hyperspecific, professor was sometimes rude when asking/answering questions
It's fast paced and the lab reports take forever to do. It was way more time-consuming than I thought it would be.

The most memorable moment in class was when Dr. G enchanted the class with his laser and vial of colored solution to demonstrate that different EMRs are absorbed on the spectrum. At these moments, the course becomes less about the mechanical actions of filling out lab reports and I learn the most. However, the grading on lab reports is unfair as different TAs grade differently and take off for small things that another grader may not. Since the course curves down, these small differences in grading serve as the difference between an A and a B. Dr. G says that he's willing to give As to every student who deserves it, but this is not manifested in the actual grading. Finally, many students, myself included, feel unnecessarily stressed with the quizzes. Although in some contexts, quizzes are essential for learning/ preparing for a lab, this course's quizzes do not add much to the learning experience. Perhaps trading the weekly quiz for an online open book pre-lab quiz due before the lab day will be beneficial.
I felt like much of the work I was doing was useless - the nitty gritty lab reports, getting 2 points off on a lab report because I forgot to retype the date, all ridiculous.

The course was effectively taught as the professor was readily available to answer the students' questions. An area of improve would be condensing the wording on the lab manuals. For instance, the manual would ask questions before answering them instead of getting straight to the point and providing useful information for the students. The large volume of nonessential text on the manuals slowed down the student during labs.

The weaknesses of this course are the quizzes and the grading of the lab reports. The instructor is incredibly picky about grading, so I found that I had to spend lots and lots of time worrying about details that were irrelevant to my learning of chemistry. (For example, worrying about whether I had included the correct number of tick marks on my graph.) Things like this were incredibly irritating, took a ton of time, and produced a lot of stress, even though they  did not make any difference in my learning.

The consistence in marking amongst the TA's needs to improve (there are some notorious TAs). Ideally if the labs were shorter it would be nice. The length of the labs were far too long; this made the time commitment for this course too much for the 0.5 credit it is worth. other labs in different courses are shorter and to the point.
More clear lab manual material could improve the class, but the pre-lab lectures were helpful in understanding material.

Strengths were that everything was spread out throughout the course of the semester. Dr. G was a great professor and I learned a lot from his prelab lecture. Sometimes the labs themselves were difficult to understand and Dr. G was not always there to explain every step of the process. The TAs were somewhat helpful but sometimes the purposes of each of the steps had to be determined alone.
I enjoyed the prelab lectures, they gave me a better understanding of the purpose of the experiment and helped answer my questions.

The course went in depth with major topics of chemistry.

The course was also very bad at allowing me to understand what was going on during these labs. I didn't know what I was doing, only that I was doing it. Of course I would go to office hours, but office hours didn't help much. I'm supposed to understand concepts explained to me during the course, not during office hours. This seems to be the general consensus of everyone that I've spoken to.
Weaknesses: Labs are overly complicated and Lap Reports are incredibly nit-picky. Course does not reward actual Chemistry knowledge or learning.

This course was painful. Some experiments seemed to lack any purpose like a full experiment devoted to taking the density of water. Other experiments seemed to be extremely repetitive. The lab reports were incredibly long and tedious, but for no apparent reason. Dr. G was never helpful but rather he rarely responded to emails and seemed to try to make our lives harder.

This is a class that you take because you have to, not because you want to. Dr. G was a good lecturer, but the stress of the impending quiz made it impossible to enjoy the learning process. 
There is absolutely no reason that every week we spent 5-12 hours typing up lab reports. I gained nothing through this painful process except a better understanding of the hoops one has to jump through in order to remain on the pre-med path.
The grading is very unfair in this class, since some TAs seem like they go out of their way to grade harshly for no reason.
The strengths are that we get to do a lot of experiments and the expectations are pretty clear.
This course is very heavy, the lab reports take a while and need a good chunk of time to complete. The labs themselves arent terrible and some are actually pretty interesting.

Strength: the labs are diverse and cover a lot of topics.
Weakness: the lab reports are graded very strictly and points are deducted for minuscule mistakes.

With the manual and prelab lecture slides on Canvas, it is easy to know what material you're accountable for and what you should study for a given week. The actual prelab lectures themselves aren't super helpful. The routine of quizzes and labs is steady and good.

Strengths: interesting labs, learn lots about conducting experiments.
Weaknesses: time consuming and only half credit. lab reports can be a lot. Grading is annoying often.
Dr. G needs to loosen up his requirements on grading. He has random and arbitrary policies that serve no apparent purpose. I'm sure he could justify them and say that he has reasons for them after years of teaching, but EVERYONE agrees, students and other teachers, that it is not good. Too handle it, all you have to do though is figure out what Dr. G wants from the lab report instructions and your TF and just follow it religiously.

The strength of this course is Dr. G. Although I rarely hear him given praise, he is easily one of the best instructors of chemistry I've ever encountered in my life  and I've had many. He follows what I think should be the golden rule for all teachers everywhere: assume the students know nothing. The pre-written lab reports were also a strength. Weaknesses include a recurring emphasis on producing "results" (less than 3% error, for example) rather than genuine data (this encourages dangerous habits!) and somewhat long and tedious lab reports (can range from 6-10 hours each, mostly depending on the fickleness of Word and Excel and Dr. G.'s demands).

One definite strength is that the course goes over a lot of the introductory chemistry topics we ought to learn but in the context of a lab. This was especially helpful for me because we didn't really touch on most of those topics in CHEM 163, but did more advanced subjects in chemistry like organic chemistry and quantum mechanics/orbital theory. That is also it's weakness, though, that there is not a lot of overlap between this course and what is taught in CHEM 163. From my understanding, it runs pretty well with CHEM 161. Maybe for the future, having some of the labs be more related to the material be related to both courses would be helpful for students to say chemistry's application, in both classes.

The strengths include the broken down instructions for lab procedure and lab report. One weakness I can think of is that I often found it very challenging to finish lab reports, especially in the beginning. So, I hope they could have tutors.

I felt zero connection with the instructor because the class was so large. I found the labs to be tedious as the TAs were unengaged. The general attitude surrounding this course was that everyone just had to get through it as a premed requirement, rather than making it fun or interesting. I found the lab reports to be tedious and not a test of our actual understanding of the course; rather, they tested how well we could carry out rote calculations and write out chemical equations. I found the grading rubrics ridiculous and nit-picky. The course seemed more about collecting points rather than making connections and understanding overarching ideas. As such I found it very disheartening.

A major weakness of this course was the lack of organization and consistency. TA's weren't well prepared, and the actual lab itself often took longer and was inefficient because no one could really figure out what was going on. Grading of the reports took a long time, and wasn't standardized, so some TA's would mark off points for certain things while others wouldn't. Also, the actual grading was so confusing: missing one sig fig or not including a reaction in the procedure would mark off absurd amounts of points, while very few points would be taken off for answering questions incorrectly. Considering the fact that Dr. G makes up his own rules for sig figs in his class, the huge emphasis on them for grading is ridiculous. 
The lab manuals and syllabus say to reach out to Dr. G or your TA several times if a concept is confusing or if you have questions. However, Dr. G is very intimidating and not easily approachable, and doesn't share information with the TA's, which is very hypocritical. Also, the lab manuals are not written clearly, and don't do a good job of easily explaining the procedure, which makes it difficult to figure out on your own. 
Additionally, all the materials that had to be purchased for this course added up to quite a lot. I had to buy a lab coat, lab notebook, pay to print out the manuals every week, a lock, a flash drive, and a calculator, which came out to a little less than $100. We weren't told about where we could find cheaper or used options, and for a student who has to pay for everything herself without help from parents, it was a lot.
Strengths were good research labs but long, sometimes tedious lab reports.
I thought the course was strong overall. The pre-lab lectures were fantastic (although the quizzes seemed unnecessary).

Dr. G is a good lecturer and yes, he is open with his hours. But there's literally no point in the quizzes. It definitely creates a disparity between those in Chem 161 and those in Chem 163 because we are learning different types of material. Though the labs did enhance my understanding of class material, I believe the quizzes were superfluous.

Strengths:  The TAs were very helpful and nice with helping during the lab and completing the lab report
Weaknesses: Labs felt very tedious. Some of them coincided with the class material, but most of it seemed kind of out of order. Only a 1/2 credit for doing the same amount of work as some full credit classes

Strengths: The course was very well organized and clear. The pre-lab lectures were effective and helpful. 
Weakness: I don't believe that the pre-lab quizzes were effective for my learning experience in the course.
This course is very picky when it comes to grading lab reports. A careless mistake could be costly to your grade on the lab report.

There aren't many strengths to this course. It was a pain in the butt and the grading was terrible and inconsistent. The only strength is that I now feel more confident in a lab setting than I did at the beginning of the semester.
I think it followed a clear structure but could of been more engaging.
The quizzes were unnecessary and the grading on the lab reports was often unnecessarily petty.
The pre-lab lectures were something long and boring.

The instructions on the lab reports were clear and the TAs and professors were usually helpful, although sometimes the instructions of the TAs were not very clear during the lab. Also, they grade lab reports very harshly. The lectures before the lab were helpful.

The strengths within this course could be found in Dr. G's prelab lectures, which I found to be very helpful and informative, and my TF, Arjun, who was incredibly helpful and allowed the students to feel confident within the lab.  There are multiple problems that lie within this course: grading on a curve where students grades may be rounded down, weekly lab quizzes without adequate ways to prepare, and the subjectivity of TF's grading of lab reports.  I believe that a student's grade should not depend on how his/her peers do.  By putting a grading system of this type in place, it creates a more cut-throat environment.  Why would an individual help his peer when ultimately that could hinder their own chances?  I believe that if a student earns a certain grade, they should be able to keep it.  I do not believe it fair, for example, for a student who earned an A- in the class to get a B+ because the class average is an A-.  Hypothetically, if the class average to be an A, it would clearly seem ridiculous to make the grade of an A equivalent to a B.  
Next, I do not believe lab quizzes should be given without the adequate tools necessary to prepare for such quizzes.
Lastly, I never was able to fully understand what I did wrong on lab reports considering certain TF's graded stricter than others.  What was okay for one TF was not necessarily okay for the next.  Because of this, it became challenging to learn from my previous mistakes and fix them.  Perhaps in the future, a TF can be assigned to grade the lab reports for another specific group.  By doing this, a student can improve and receive a better grade.

The course was good in giving first hand experience in how to use lab equipment and properly handle tools. It was weak in that the lab reports were not conducive to learning how things work in actual labs and grading was very particular for issues that were not very important.

Some strengths are that it is very intensive and requires a lot of concentration, allowing for focused laboratory work. Weaknesses include the fact that Dr. G uses a different method of significant figures, which is confusing when taken alongside the lecture course, and the seemingly arbitrary grading criteria used by the lab TFs when they grade lab reports.

Strengths: 
We were able to work with some cool chemicals and observe amazing demonstrations.  

Weakness: 
The lab reports were difficult to complete because we often did not know what the graders were looking for.
I think that this course definitely helps students better understand chemistry. I feel as though the quizzes can be difficult at times and discouraging.

It felt as though no matter how much attention I paid to detail on my lab reports, I couldn't get above a B.

Also, this isn't a flaw of the course itself, but it should be worth a full credit, not a half credit - four hours a week plus the intensity of the lab reports

The course could be improved in: longer time for the quizzes, time before the lab starts to discuss the entire procedure, practice exercises for the quizzes during lecture. I would also recommend more TA's for smaller groups.

This lab is the only option for students enrolled in Chem 163, despite not being related whatsoever to the material presented in lectures. One weakness of this course is that not enough review is given for students in Chem 163 prior to taking the pre-lab quizzes. Although the content of the quizzes is well within the realm of knowledge students in Chem 163 should have, the time gap between learning such information and the quizzes is often too large to guarantee that these students are given a fair chance when asked to remember specific equations that are not needed to engage with material in Chem 163. A more thorough review of equations should be given, or included in the pre-lab material.

This course did a good job of teaching me how to use lab resources. Often, the content covered in lab didn't line up with the content taught in my chemistry lecture, which probably would have been helpful. Another weakness of the course is that it is only worth half a credit toward my distributional requirements, yet the class took up just as much time (both in lab and outside of lab with lab reports and lab prep) as many of my other classes, with grade deductions for things that didn't really seem to have any impact on my actual understanding of the material. That said, a strength of the course was the grading policy that allows one lab to be dropped. One of the biggest strengths of this course was the TF's. My TF was Arjun, and he was fantastic and made lab a more fun and easier to understand experience, but most of the TF's that I encountered were helpful and very nice. In addition to the TF's, a major strength of this course was that it allowed (and in some ways necessitated) that I connect with other students, most of whom were fellow pre-med students who I was able to collaborate with and become friends with.
I think its good, the work you put in is the work you get in return

The strengths are that it teaches you to be patient and that each lab report has a prepared layout and the weaknesses are that there are quizzes during every lecture and there is a heavy emphasize on the grading of the lab reports, you are not told exactly how to get full points and points are taken off for small things often.

Some quizzes were unnecessarily difficult and specific. Its impossible to know for what information points will be given or deducted on the lab reports. Its a tough class that probably requires a full credit worth of time but it really teaches you how to handle a lab course and the TAs are generally good.
the professor is not the best
The course gave us adequate time to complete the lab reports and labs were always carefully explained and supervised. It was very well organized.
I think the pre lab lectures are essential  understanding the lab but the lab manuals could be laid out a bit more clearly.
The quizzes were skewed in favor of 161 students.
The class is very well organized and gave a great deal of feedback, more than I have experienced in other courses.
I think that this course is somewhat interesting, but some of the labs were very tedious and long.

Strengths include having the manuals long before the lab

Weaknesses include not many possibilities to ask questions
I think the strengths are the prelectures given before we perform the labs.
The only thing that could improve this course is for to reduce the time length. 1-5 is longer than needed.

It is great for learning how to work in a lab setting. However, the grading of lab reports is somewhat pedantic, and the material we studied in this class rarely lined up with the general chemistry class.
The course was informative but the grading was really not standardized between graders.

The strength of the course is the numerous experiments that we perform. The lab reports not only help us learn how to write scientifically, but also help us better understand scientific concepts. In the future, I would really appreciate having a faster turn-around on the feedback for our graded lab reports so that I can improve lab reports in the future.
I thought that the labs were a little tedious and the labs themselves were not that interesting.
liked most of the labs a lot; wish that we could choose the lab report format (eg. use LaTeX).

Firstly, I believe the course should be worth 1.0 credits, rather than 0.5 credits, because it is incredibly time consuming. While it was not always intellectually challenging, the combined time of typing up the lab report, preparing for the next lab and the lab itself, was more than what a full credit course required I found. I thought the pre-lab lecture often cleared things up. 

However, feedback was very limited and it was never in a timely fashion.  lab reports were returned two, if not three weeks after the deadline. The lab report grades and comments came out two weeks after the due date, at which point the feedback was not very useful, since many experiments were similar to the next one. By the time the feedback was available for the first one, I had already submitted any lab report that would have made the feedback relevant and helpful.

This class was really draining and took a tremendous amount of time (5 hours a week just for the class, plus a lot of out of class work). I think the prelab lectures could be way shorter, and the quizzes are unnecessary.

The course definitely reinforced the concepts I learned in the lecture course (CHEM 161), and the two courses overlapped well. Dr. G taught us well, he taught us a lot, and he taught us fast. The lab quizzes were a good level of difficulty. I loved that we got a detailed template for each lab report. The lab manuals were also nicely detailed. One weakness of this course was that the feedback on the lab reports was not always very clear. Also, the workload was too much for the course to only be worth half of a credit. The course's meeting time was also very long, making for an exhausting day. The large size of the course made it easy to get lost in the crowd and fall behind.
The graded lab reports are given back to the students 2 weeks after submission and so I did not know what mistakes I made in the previous lab report and therefore repeated those mistakes.
Give a rubric for all lab reports instead of just the first one.
I loved the course and the only weakness would be the grading was very slow so you couldnt learn from your mistakes. It would also be helpful if it was a full credit because its alot of work.
I think the course is very strong with few to no weaknesses.
Fast paced and extremely interactive.

Strengths are that it taught me how to work together with the students and TA around me during lab, and it taught me patience, persistence, and attention to details. Weakness was that, sometimes, the graders were a bit picky for the lab reports, causing me to lose unnecessary points.

One strength is that the lab themselves are pretty good. 
Weaknesses: each lab report is a lot of work, each lab requires a lot of preparation, and the class is only half a credit.

The pre lab lectures are very interesting and Dr G is very knowledgeable about what he teaches. The quizzes right after the pre lab lectures are often very difficult and unfair at times since some questions/problems are implied that students just have the chemistry background instead of being from the lab manual for the lab day. They are also graded unfairly where a simple mistake in one calculation but with the correct problem solving/theory is docked all points.

The lab reports are graded unfairly. Little mistakes like significant figures should not be deducted so many points if the student understands the purpose and the calculations for each report.

The strengths of this course: allows for self-growth due to the challenging nature of each assignment. The weaknesses of this course: it is made much more stressful than is necessary because of how it is taught.

I thought the pre-lab lectures were very good: Dr. G was very good at explaining everything and clearing up how to do the calculations. I also thought the lab report pages were very helpful since it was basically just a template you had to fill out, and there wasn't a lot of typing out a whole lab report that we had to do. I will say the grading of lab reports was very picky. I thought a major weakness was this course is geared towards students in CHEM 161. I took CHEM 163 and sometimes there would be stuff I didn't know on the quizzes that was covered in 161 but not 163, and I had to try to remember the information from when I learned it in high school 2 years ago.
More interesting experiments that improvement more than one skill

One strength is the Professors availability as well as the coordination of the course with general chemistry. However one weakness is that assignments sometimes are vague and lead to confusion. While this encourages students to visit the professor which is a plus and often times sorts out the problem there were times where I wish instructions were more clear in class.

I thought having a lecture before the lab itself was really useful in understanding what the lab actually entailed. I did think however that the grading was sometimes unclear as different instructors would mark off for different things.
Strengths involved clear feedback on lab reports, detailed instruction sheets, and good TAs. Dr. G also gave helpful pre-lab lectures.

Strengths: It makes you work hard, which makes you learn a lot. Pre-lab lecture is fun and interesting, if you don't think too much about the quiz and just focus on DR. G's wonderful lecturing.

Weaknesses: I'm not sure what I would change.
Dr. G was a good teacher, but how the lab reports were graded was still unclear. It seemed like each TA had their own interpretation of the rubric, which needed to be standardized.
Too much work for not enough credit.

Strength: very helpful lectures by Dr. G. 
Weakness: they do not give clear instructions about the lab reports in terms of what they expect on each different one.

The strength of this course is the resources we are provided to carry out the experiments. The weakness is the way in which the course is graded. Everything is curved down--meaning that if you technically earned in 'A' (percentage-wise), you could still end up with a 'B' because it's the class average.

This course was very tedious. Actually performing the experiments was long but manageable, but Dr. G's lab rubric is unnecessarily harsh and focused too much on the insignificant parts of a lab report instead of the actual science and the process of learning. The prelab quizzes are particularly stressful because you couldn't really study/prepare for them other than reading the manual, which usually wasn't enough. Also feedback on lab reports was slow.
The course is very time-intensive. While I do think that it assisted my understanding of the concepts in General Chemistry, I dont think it needs to be so rigorous for only a half-credit course.

Strengths: went over concepts in depth, lectures were thorough, TAs were really nice and responsive.

Weaknesses: lab reports and labs themselves were overly complicated, lab manuals were often unclear and had clear spelling, grammar, and organizational issues, lab report grading was sporadic and unreflective of understanding of material, feedback was untimely and often unhelpful, actual lab procedures were repetitive and poorly set up to facilitate actual learning.
Lab reports could be graded less harshly. By that, I mean that a more clear rubric for what is expected from each lab report should be provided.

This course does a good job of introducing students to different types of lab methods.
However, this course is very tedious and not focused on the right thing.  We should be focusing on learning how to work in a lab rather than on making small mistakes (significant figures, forgetting a heading, etc.) that are not the important part of the course.
The material from lab doesn't really help me understand cam 161 concepts.

The strengths include the inclusion of worked-out example problems/calculations in the lab manuals because they really make the real lab work go more smoothly. And those examples also help facilitate better understanding.

As for weaknesses, I think the lab manuals at time were a bit too wordy/lengthy and lab report expectations were not always clearly communicated. I think that example lab reports should also be provided after the first lab.

A strength is the TAs.

Weakness is the pace.
Stop grading the lab reports so harshly on things that dont matter.
Well organized, but geared toward Chem 161 students, so as a Chem 163 student it took more work to do well.
The strengths of this course include the lab manual procedures and the progression of lab skills taught. The weaknesses included faulty equipment.

The course was well taught and questions were answered thoroughly. All concerns were addressed promptly and clearly. I feel the course could be improved by having lab quizzes about the lab was completed, rather than before. This would allow for more time to fully understand the lab.

Strengths: Hands on and practical. Also, some of the experiments help enrich understanding of the concepts

Weaknesses: Sometimes it is confusing why certain things are done in an experiment. For an example, it was not very clear from the pre-lab lecture or notes why one needed to use an electric current during the calorimetry experiments.  Aside from that, the workload seems a bit much.

Weaknesses- Quizzes should not be counted as part of the class grade. They are useless and difficult for no reason. It is also a lot of work for half a credit. 
strengths- Pre-lab lectures that teach you a little bit before you do the experiment.

The course is good at helping develop lab skills and incorporating chemistry concepts from 161 or 163 into the lab for that week. the lab reports are generally manageable however the grading between TA's are very inconsistent. Additionally, the quizzes are often unnecessarily difficult.

This course's strength is that students are able to keep detailed lab notes as well as perform basic lab procedures very well by the end of the course. However, this course could improve by attempting to make sure that all of the lab work required can be completed within one lab period without students having to rush.
It is very long and tedious. Also there could be more preparation for the quizzes.

One weakness is that the course is a lot of busy work the lab reports are particularly arduous, and I never felt like I learned much from them. I think that aspect of the class could be streamlined for a more enjoyable and efficient student experience (the sample calculations in particular are an absolute pain to write out, and at least in my experience real labs do not require the level of detail these lab reports insist upon). However, I do think the class gets a bit of a bad rap. Besides the aforementioned lab reports, I found the actual lab days pretty enjoyable, if occasionally stressful, and if you put in work and are meticulous about the lab reports the grading is not too bad.

Weakness: This course emphasizes mostly on how well the report is presented, and much less on the chemistry itself. Therefore, a "sloppy report" with a 0.2% error analysis is likely to receive a lower grade than one with a 60% error analysis that is presented with a better format. In this way, to be successful in this chemistry lab minute details such as lab formatting, partner names, dates, sig figs have a higher emphasis than a correct procedure. Another weakness is that some students know that extra credit is given for standard deviation, while many more do not. This seems unfair to me that the same knowledge is not given equally to all.
Sometimes the amount of work to be completed in a given class period was quite large and difficult to complete.
Hands-on experience is fun, but the lab manuals were sometimes confusing and/or poorly edited and there was way too much focus on significant figures.

The course is a comprehensive introduction to lab practices and it manages to walk students through a lot of different lab techniques during the semester. Nonetheless, I believe that as a student of CHEM 163 this lab course was completely disjointed from what I was taught in my introductory chemistry lecture course. There was no clear connection between the topics taught in CHEM 163 as opposed to the intimate connection that existed between the topics of CHEM 134L and CHEM 161. This may have made the lab course seem pointless at times, as it did not build upon the concepts that were taught in lecture in order to analyze in an empirical context. Another weakness of the course was for me the way n which the lab reports were graded. And by saying that, I do not purely mean the way in which points were deducted from the lab reports; rather, I focus on the fact that the lab reports were corrected slowly, not allowing for improvement in a student's work. More specifically, there lab reports were returned to us corrected two weeks after we submitted them. Bearing in mind that a lab report was due on a weekly basis, it was many times the case that the mistakes that were made on one report were repeated on the next one, as the students were unable to identify their mistakes and correct them promptly. Furthermore, the many times excessive focus on detail caused frustration in the students and created a tense relation with the lab course that was unnecessary. Another frustrating aspect of the course, were definitely the pre-lab quizzes. I believe that the quizzes had no other aim other than purely testing how good a student was at retaining the information that was taught in the pre-lab lecture for several minutes and reproducing them at a ridiculous speed in the quiz. There were no skills or critical thinking tested in the quizzes; it was all a matter of mere memorization, something that caused frustration at times, especially when paired with the very harsh grading. All in all, although the course was a thorough introduction to lab practices, I believe that it is necessary that some of its weaknesses are corrected in order for it to be a more effective in its aim.
The strengths are that the class is very well structured.  The weaknesses are that for some people the responsibility of knowing whats actually happening in the class is entirely one themselves.

The strengths of this course are the teaching and the amount of material examined, however, I believe the testing and extreme time constraints for completing each laboratory experiment are severe weaknesses.  To address the weaknesses, the material could be taught prior to the quiz day, and to complete the experiments more comfortably in the given time, the experiment could consist of fewer objectives.

The course effectively teaches the basics of the chemistry lab. The pre-lab lectures provide a good understanding of not only the subsequent labs but also of chemistry as a whole. I often used the information learned in the pre-lab lectures to study for the exams in CHEM 161. 

The major weakness of this course is that it fosters an environment of cheating. The strict requirements inside and outside the lab (both while following the procedure and while writing the lab report), coupled with the time constraints of lab time and the accuracy requirement for laboratory results (for example, when all calculated R values had to have a percent deviation of less than 3%), encouraged students to alter their results to produce results that matched with what the instructor wanted to see. For instance, some people, when calculating the gas constant R in the Lab #9, obtained a value of R that deviated from the accepted value of R by greater than 3%. These people then altered the measured volume on their data sheets so that the calculated R would fall within that 3% range, without redoing the trial. Faking scientific results, especially in today's society, is totally unacceptable, and I believe that this course could be taught in a way that would discourage, rather than encourage, this falsification. The practice and enactment of true science should always be more important than the results received.

A strength is that you get to apply the knowledge learned from chemistry lecture in lab, which helps to cement that information. A weakness is that the class time is pretty long, partly due to pre-lab lectures and quizzes that last up to an hour. Most of the information covered in the pre-lab lecture is already covered in regular chemistry lecture and in the lab manual we have to read before lab so it is not really necessary to have such a long lecture right before the lab. Also the quizzes expected us to memorize really specific, kind of random, information that was on the lab manual, which was pointless since we were allowed to use the lab manual when carrying out the actual experiments so we did not really need to have the information memorized.

They're should be better feedback regarding what is expected of lab reports. In addition, what is required of lab reports is rarely ever clear before they're due. The expectations should be made more clear.

This course just seemed like an unnecessary weed-out. The curriculum did not correlate to my chemistry course at all, so there was little learning. It was really just about sig figs. 

Additionally, this course should absolutely be worth more than a half credit. If you add it up, I spend more time physically in lab than in chemistry lecture  classes all week, we have quizzes every week, and the workload is much greater than chemistry.

The strengths of this course were all the resources that ensured you knew what to do during the lab itself. While the prelab was sometimes confusing, the lecture and your teaching fellow made sure you knew what to do during the lab and what steps to follow, so while you may walk into the lab anxious, you would still be able to complete the lab. A weakness of this course, I believe, is the disconnect between the lab itself and the lab reports. Often, even if you followed all the steps for the lab and wrote everything down, you would still be missing information needed to write the lab report. In addition, the teaching fellows do not all grade to the same standards. That being said, Dr. G's office hours are a huge help.
I would not recommend this course unless you must take it. It is a lot of work, so it is difficult to enjoy the process of doing experiments.
Only if you need it as a prerequisite/premed.

I would recommend this course if only to learn the practical chemistry. It is a lot of work, especially for a half credit class, but it is rewarding work. I did learn a lot, but I would warn others of its difficulty and workload
Take it because you have to as a prereq.  It is a lot of work for only a half a credit, though.
Yes, it teaches required lab skills and doing the labs is quite absorbing.
Yes, however I dislike the fact that grading focuses on format so much.

I would, but only if the person were prospectively going into a field related to chemistry in which research is important. Otherwise, the course is not required and is a significant workload (especially if the work is not carried out in a timely fashion), so I would not recommend it to people not interested in studying chemistry.
Only if it's a requirement. I have no idea why you would want to take this lab otherwise.
The course isn't bad, but it also isn't particularly interesting and can be stressful.
The class is challenging and not an easy grade but it is reasonable and is worth the time and effort.

The only people that take chem lab are the people who need it for their major or premed requirements. At that point there's no point in recommending this course because nobody really makes a choice about taking it.
Not unless you need it
Yes. However, I would warn them that the workload is a bit high for a course that's only half-credit.

Eh, I would if they want to get a greater understanding of chemistry, but with that being said I think there is a lot of unnecessary tediousness in the class that should be eliminated. While there is waiting around time in science, as a course this should be more engaging and some of the labs were very painful to perform and the reports sometimes asked for a lot of work unnecessarily.
Don't take this course unless you have to. Save yourself the 15 minute cardio session from old campus.

If you're pre-med or just a STEM person, you probably have to take it anyway. But even so, yeah, I would recommend it! I liked it even if it got frustrating and stressful at times. I still enjoyed the basic science behind the experiments; it was cool to see the chemistry from the textbook in real life.

I would not recommend this course to another student. If I didn't have to take this course for my major I would not have completed it. The amount of stress due to this course inhibits proper learning of the concepts I should be furthering my understanding of in the course. I found that for each lab I was always more concerned with getting the "proper results" that the instructor expected from us rather than actually understanding what I was doing and learning from the lab procedures.
I would recommend this course to another student because it teaches valuable skills that will be used in future chemistry and lab classes.
I wouldn't recommend it unless you had to take it.
Only if required for STEM major or premed.
I would recommend this to any student on a pre-med track because it is required, but if you are not pre-med or majoring in chemistry, I would not recommend this course.
No.  Unfortunately this class is set up for students to focus not on the material but on the astringent grading guidelines and nit picky rubrics.
I think that it is useful for a first experience in labs.
Absolutely not.
I would recommend this course only if the student was willing to put in the work to do well. The course is very informative, but it is also very unforgiving.
No. Do not take this course unless it is a requirement.

If you're taking this it's most likely a requirement, and I'd say it's not a terrible one. A good TA and a good lab partner will make the work bearable, and it's honestly not an enormous amount of work overall.
Unless you're pre-med, don't take this course.
I would not recommend to someone who isn't interested in science, but I think it is a great lab for someone entering the STEM areas, particularly chem.
I don't think I would recommend this course to people who are not required to take it. It is an extremely high workload for only a 1/2 credit course.
Yes. I think it was a good introduction to the lab, but I would warn them that the lab reports take more time than expected.

I would recommend it if you want some hands-on experience with chemistry experiments. The experiments we do are hardcore and are much more involved than high school chemistry experiments. Yes, I would absolutely recommend this. Even though you will probably need to take this because it is a pre-req, it was a very pleasant experience. Other people have bashed this course, but I have not had that same experience.
Only take the course if you need to; otherwise, no. It's an unnecessary source of stress.

I would only recommend this course to students who need it to fill a requirement, because the labs done are so basic and elementary that you really dont get anything out of it except a filled requirement.
If they are premed, and they have not placed into organic chemistry, then they would unfortunately have to take this course.
Because I am pre-med, I recommend this course because I have to. There is no other way to go to medical school.

I would recommend this course to another student. It was a good introduction to chemistry. Of course there are many quirks in this course like sigfigs and the proper way to do a lab report, but I feel like for the most part, I have become more careful and I learned a lot in chemistry.
Yes, its also a necessary lab course and provides an ample foundation for other works

No. This course is almost completely useless and one's time can be much better spent in other courses. It is a shame that a course like this is offered at such an expensive and prestigious institution as Yale. Unfortunately it is a pre-req for many majors.

I did think some of the work was tedious and seemed a bit extraneous, so the class as a whole felt like it required a lot more work and energy than it was supposed to.
I would recommend the course in that it is perfectly tolerable and sometimes quite interesting; chem lab has a worse reputation than it deserves, and I actually enjoyed certain aspects of lab.

This course was very engaging and a great supplement for the material I learned in Chem 161, however, the grading for the lab reports was unreasonably harsh.  Dr. G was definitely very passionate about the material and very helpful. My only contention would be the grading and that it is only half a credit despite the workload. I would recommend this course only to students that need this for their major or pre-medical studies.
I would recommend this course to another student because, although it is difficult at times, you gain a really solid understanding about how to set up experiments and how to create a lab report.
I would recommend this course to another student. The lab skills I gained will serve me well in the future.

I would recommend this course to any student at Yale because I believe that it was a generally engaging and entertaining course. I loved Dr. G as an instructor and the chemistry as a subject, so I would completely recommend this to anyone interested in chemistry or just wanting a fun course.
I would never recommend this course to a student unless it fulfills some prerequisite for their major.

Don't stress out about this course. Some people spend 8-12 hours on lab reports to get an A and honestly, since most people take this in their first year, don't do this. no not unless they need it as a requirement because its not a fun course and we get curved down which seems unfair given that the class mean is quite high and students with grades in the 90s should receive an A regardless of how others do. Yes, Chem lab isn't bad. A lot of students come in thinking it's going to be aweful. Yes because despite the courses difficulty, it forces us to learn the necessary lab and lab report skills so that going forward in the lab it becomes easier and more manageable.
I would recommend this course to another student only if it was required of them or if they want to gain experience in the lab. The class did a good job of introducing students to the lab.
As a required course, I guess I would recommend this course because it could have been a lot worse. However, as a class to take for fun or to learn something new, I would not recommend this course.

I would not recommend this course to another student. Taking this chemistry lab is mandatory in order to fulfill pre-med requirements, and that is the ONLY reason I would suggest another individual take this course.

I would recommend this course to another student considering it is great preparation for future work in the STEM field. There is small room for error, and as long as directions are followed, it is pretty easy to understand. Grading is a bit harsh but it helps you improve for future courses.
