Would recommend only if taken to fulfill a requirement ("premed"). Do not take the course for fun because there are more fun and way more interesting labs to take at Yale.

No. No one takes this lab because they want to. Everyone takes it because they have to. It sucks, and I'm sorry. It would be great if Dr. G was responsive to many years of criticism, but frustratingly, he is not, so it seems unlikely that this course will improve.

If you're looking at this class, chances are you have to take it, so recommendations mean very little. That being said, if you know the challenges of the course then it might be easy to tackle them when they come.

Do not take this class unless you absolutely need to for you major. There is little redeeming value in the labs planned out by the professor. Grading is overly harsh and at times can feel unfair. The amount of time required to do well in this class is disproportional to the amount of credit received. There are other lab courses that are far more engaging than this one.

No. Albeit moderately helpful, I would not say that this class was a particularly fun experience. A lot of the lab reports were extremely monotonous and graded very harshly. Additionally, the atmosphere during lab was usually one of stress and anxiety.
I would not recommend this course to anyone else unless it's required for your major. All the time and effort you put into this class is not worth 0.5 credits.

No. Only take this course if you absolutely have to. It's time consuming, stressful, and you do not learn anything. It's a requirement for many premed tracks, so that is the only reason anyone should take this.

I would NOT recommend this course. it is a nessecary evil for all PreMed and STEM majors. I learned nothing in the end, and it required more work and time than the CHEM 161 accompanying class, which literally taught all of the material.

Maybe, it is required for a lot of prerequisites, and the pre-med track. That being said, the course is a lot of work and should be worth more than half a credit. It was the same amount of work if not more than other one credit classes and the amount of time spent in class is just as much as well. yes I would, it is involving but fun.
No. The only reason why students take this course is because of premed requirements.
If you need it for a major take it early and get this nightmare over with.
Only if required (for example if one is going premed).
Absolutely not, grading is unfair and Dr. G can be harsh for no reason.

The class is most likely a requirement, but its not that bad. The lab reports take a while at first, but it gets easier with time. The expectations for the reports are pretty clear and there is plenty of feedback. Dr. G cares about the subject matter and makes himself available to answer any questions and will help when writing the lab reports.
I would take this course if you have a genuine interest in chemistry or need the credit.
I would recommend this course to students interested in sciences but otherwise its a lot of work for someone that is not at all interested.

Yes. Although most people are just taking it as part of some pre-STEM major requirement, it's usually enjoyable once you get into the lab and get your hands on whatever the experiment is that day. The quizzes and lab reports themselves aren't super fun (what assessment is?), but the TAs are generally really helpful and the class is a good experience overall.
Yes
Yes. You have to do it, and it's not too bad. Just learn the details and make it happen.

A good number of majors require this class, so you'll probably be forced to take it like I was. If you can help it, however, make sure you take this class with some professor other than Dr. G. There are a number of problems with this class - which I'm sure Dr. G. is aware of, as he took the time at the last day of class to stand in front of each of his lectures and beg for a positive review ("Please put aside any complaints you have about the class, and review me as an instructor who is competent enough to teach chemistry :)"). Footnote, Dr. G. somehow has learned to speak the smile emoticon - that is how condescending he is. He chides the class for not being prepared when nobody has a question, but when someone does ask a question it's met with "oh, honey, bless your soul" levels of condescension (which he delivers only after moving across the entire lecture hall, if necessary, to stand directly in front of you. To ensure you're in striking distance, I assume.). 
Regardless, this class will serve as an excellent intro to the phrase "twice the work, half the credit." Dr. G. has bizarre sig fig rules that he expects you to memorize and use for his class, which directly contradict the rules used by the gen chem lecture classes (and, coincidentally, the rest of the world.).
Quizzes are given on the laboratory technique prior to the lab, which makes sense and I suppose helps with being prepared before the lab, but are nonetheless inconvenient and because I am petty I will complain about them.
I did learn a number of basic lab techniques, and for the semester I was in a cohort of 300 or so people who had similar complaints about the class, further reinforcing  my comfort with my Yale Family(TM). In this course, you will also learn how to control your blood pressure while you run through 8 trials in 2 hours because Dr. G. has decided that you must calculate physical constants using experimental results to an insane degree of accuracy: Avogadro's constant with 3% error or less is not the best way to spend your Friday, so don't subject yourself to this class on the pre-weekend if you must subject yourself at all.
In summary, I complained. You will witness and experience a lot of that if you take this class.

If you're reading this, it's probably too late. Maybe you want to go to medical school. Maybe you want to pursue a degree in chemical engineering. Maybe you just want to feel like a scientist. Either way, one semester of this course will be enough to defile your enthusiasm for chemistry and strip you of any scrap of mental sanity you think you might possess. I did not learn how to balance a redox reaction in this course. I did not gain any new insight into the electromagnetic spectrum. Instead, I learned how to anxiously triple-check my significant digits on a graduated cylinder, and more memorably, how to hold my breath in pure terror when Dr. G walks into the lab. 

It is not impossible to get an A in this class. You can reap academic success if you allocate your time proactively and strategically. More specifically, read every single word of the 28 page syllabus and befriend your TA; it'll save you dozens of points in the long-run. However, even though there are steps you can take to do well in this class, this half credit still managed to impose an irreparable mental burden on my first semester of college. So, if you feel like you're just shopping this class on a whim, please, please, PLEASE critically ask yourself if you actually need to take CHEM 134L for your prospective major and / or career path. Run, if you still can.

Absolutely not unless you are required to. Since most of you reading this ARE required to, I'm sorry, but I guess you'll have to suck it up until things change. On the bright side, Dr. G. is a gem and his lectures are often better and more helpful than Gen Chem's lectures on each topic. If only he could teach that instead!
I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in chemistry and getting involved with it in a lab setting. And obviously, someone who plans to major in chemistry
Yes, only if they truly need it.
Absolutely not. The only reason to take this course is because it is a premedical requirement, which I find very unfortunate.
Yes, if and only if you're going into pre-med.
I would recommend it because it provides a less stressful introduction to lab work.
Only if you're doing premed. This course is a waste of time and further drains the precious time that you have left.
Take it only if you need to take it as pre-med.
I would not recommend it unless you have to get the course out of the way for pre-med requirements
Yes. I recommend this course towards anyone who wants to learn about chemistry in a manner that is both challenging and engaging.

I would not recommend this course to another student unless they had to take it as a requirement. Grading is not easy, there are quizzes every week, and it Is four hours out of your day. The workload that is put into this course is definitely deserving of more than half a credit.

I wouldn't recommend this course to anyone unless they absolutely have to take it. The TA's do not understand the concept of consistent grading, and Dr. G never seemed to be in a good mood. The grading rubric is incredibly strict, with many of the point values for parts of the lab report seemingly skewed. The pre-lecture quizzes were terrible and Dr. G's made-up rules for significant figures were just about the worst thing in the world.
Not really, wasn't really engaging and I don't think the course focused on giving students feedback on where they were struggling over concepts.
It is a necessary course so I guess its semi-recommended.

I would not recommend this course unless it is a requirement because the lab reports take a very long time to complete and points are taken off for small details, and the course is only half a credit. However, if you need to learn about and get comfortable in a lab, this is a good course.
Not at all.
It's literally the only gen chem lab offered so you kind of have to take it if its required for your major or premed.
I learned valuable lab skills and would recommend this course as it is an important prerequisite for many majors.
Yes, it is necessary to develop the fundamentals of laboratory work for chemistry and acts as a supplement to the lecture course.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student if they needed to complete it for their area of study.  I would not recommend this class to students who did not need to take it, as the workload was higher than any of my other courses.
yes
Only take if you have to
Yes, Dr. G is strict in the best way, he makes you really focus on detail
I wouldn't. The amount of stress and anxiety the laboratory gave me I wouldn't wish on anybody else.

As a pre-med student at Yale, this is a course that must be taken. That said, I would tell other pre-meds who have not yet taken the course that it really isn't that bad and they can make it through it just fine.
You probably have to take it anyways, but its not as bad as people make it out to be
I would recommend it only if the student needs it (like if they are a pre-med or chemistry student).
no, this course was the bane of my existence.
Yes, as it is a good introduction into basic techniques in chemistry.
Yes, I think its engaging and interesting.
Yes. Although the class is challenging, it greatly expanded my knowledge of chemistry.
I would not recommend this course to another Yale student. The only reason why I took it was because I have to fulfill my chemistry labs for my major.
Yes you need to take this for pre med. but takes up a lot of time for 1/2 a credit.
Its a tough course but essential to learn how to work in a lab.
Yes.
I would recommend this course to any pre-med student - (1) because it is a pre-med pre-requisite and (2) because it actually does help solidify scientific communication skills.
Yes, but only if you are interested in doing chem lab work.

take if you are pre-med/ a chem major, since it is a requirement. as labs go, it was pretty great, but at the end of the day it's still only 0.5 credits, so I wouldn't take it if it weren't necessary for me.
I would if they needed to learn basic experimental procedures. Though most were boring and tedious, there is no other course at Yale at the moment that offers these skills.

Most people taking chem lab are likely doing it to fulfill a requirement, not for fun. If you are taking it as a requirement, theres not much you can do except tough it out. The class is really time consuming and tiring, but doable.
no

You'll probably only want to take this course if it's a requirement for you. Everybody hates on this course, but it's really not that bad. Some of the labs themselves are pretty fun and relaxing (most don't take the whole three hours), and only one or two of the lab reports are really tedious. However, the course is a lot of work for just half of a credit. I will say that the labs reinforced the chemistry concepts I learned in the lecture course (CHEM 161), and the two courses often overlapped well.
If you are looking at premed, then yes, it is a requirement. If you are taking chemistry just to learn it, then you don't need to, but it is interesting.
Yes
Yes- it is very effective in teaching chemistry in a hands on way.

I do not recommend this course unless it is needed as a pre requisite. The course requires way too much time for 0.5 credit.

Yes! I loved this lab! I was nervous going in because all the reviews were negative, but I thought this was a pretty simple and easy class. Many reviews complained about the workload, but I didn't think it was a lot of work. Most of the lab reports I could sit down the day before it was do and finish it in one sitting. I thought the experiments were fun too, and working with lab partners is a great way to meet new friends.
Only take if its required

I personally enjoyed the lab and found the availability of the professor to be a nice convenience. I also found that the material covered in lab class complemented the material in general chemistry particularly spot on and reinforced skills on both ends. However I do not recommend this course to a student who is not willing or does not have time as Lab does take a fair portion of time out of the week and assignments while not terribly long do take a fair amount of judgement and time to complete
Yes I would because it provided a strong understanding of basic lab procedure.

If you are taking this course it is likely because you have to for your major. It's not as bad as everyone says it is! I have fond memories of being in lab. The lab reports are a lot of work and take a while but that's impossible to get around.
I would only recommend this course to another student if they were pre-med.

Only if you're interested in chemistry. Most people have to take this for pre-med or their major, so it's not like you can really avoid it, but if you're someone who's just looking for an interesting laboratory course and doesn't have to take this there are definitely better options out there.
No.

I'm guessing most students who take this class don't really have much of a choice, but in case there's some kid out there who wants to take this just for fun, my answer is a strong no. The grading is arbitrary, Dr. G seems to make an effort to be as unapproachable as possible, and the content doesn't line up at all with the curriculum of Chem 163. Overall, this class involved a lot of stress and very little learning. Finishing my last lab would have been the happiest day of semester if I didn't feel dead inside from the rest of the course.
This was probably the class I looked forward to least throughout the semester, since it was up to 4 hours on a Friday afternoon, so no.

This course is required if one wants to major in most of the sciences or if one wants to prepare for medical school. Therefore, there is no point in me recommending this course, as the students that are interested in it are students that have to take it. My opinion is that if a student does not lie in the above mentioned categories then they should not take this course, for the reason that it mostly builds on the theoretical knowledge gained in introductory  chemistry lectures to introduce empirical topics.
Yes, taking this class is an important part of an education.  You learn many interesting and important reactions that help you understand the living world around you.

I would not recommend this course.  This is due to the demanding nature of the course coupled with the little intellectual reward it offers.  The lab reports are graded very harshly and points are deducted for many reasons outside of the academic, and it is unclear what must be done to achieve perfection on the lab reports.  The information on the quizzes are taught immediately before the quizzes are administered.  The experiments are often encouraged to be performed carefully and slowly, however, the time constraint requires that one rushes to the point of making mistakes, spills, etc.

I would. However, I would caution that this course has an extremely strenuous workload for only a half-credit course, and not all components of the class are entirely enjoyable. A love of chemistry helps get one through this course.
No because it is time-consuming and not engaging. Plus it is worth only half a credit.
Im not sure. It has its bright spots but it can also be extremely stressful and not very rewarding.
Def not. But it's a requirement for a lot of stuff. I enjoyed some parts, like doing titrations, but mainly it was just stressful.

For a half-credit course, this class provided the bulk of my courseload each week. The lab reports often took hours, and preparing for the next lab also took some time. I would only recommend this course if you needed it as a prerequisite (whether it be for pre-med or for your major); do not just take it for a science credit. I would definitely recommend taking it if you are already taking Chemistry 161 because it is better understood when you are taking both at the same time.
